title: Who sang 'Eleanor Rigby' by the Beatles? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Eleanor Rigby was Paul’s BABY; I helped with the Education of the Child”. [ Music by The Beatles, Sarcasm by, well, you know…]. Eleanor Rigby is my favourite song off the Avant Guard MeisterWerke ‘Revolver’because it was so utterly unexpected & ‘Anti-Rock’. After hearing Eleanor Rigby, for the first time, I exclaimed: “This is not Rock, this is…the FUTURE!!! Paul, (John & George) sang backup. Think about it? It’s a pulsing song propelled by nothing but angular staccato strings—its Jimi Hendrex’s ‘Purple Haze’ for the high brow Vivaldi set… Why is Eleanor Rigby ‘Anti-Rock’? First, it’s not a Love Song by any stretch of the imagination. Who but The Beatles would DARE write a song about the marginalization & Loneliness of Britain’s Elderly, in 1966, and get away with it? “Dave (Clark), I give it a 1, you really can’t dance to it and it’s so depressing…” Second, there is not a single Rock Instrument played on the track yet you can still stage dive & head walk to it!!! FYI, I always hated the gimmicky Revolver version; you want the 2015 remix off of ONE. Fifth Beatle George Martin scored the piece for an OCTET as influenced by Bernard Hermann. Maverick Recording Engineer Geoff Emerick wanted the song to be the opposite of ‘Yesterday’ so he went for close miking of their instruments which, in 1966, wasn’t done ✅. How did the Octet react? In unison, they slid their chairs 🪑 back—which caused an exasperated George Martin to scream “STOP MOVING THE CHAIRS”!!! The Octet recorded the song 28APR1966 and the song is as beloved & exciting to hear 54 years later. The Sixties were the height of Rock with the 80’s it’s Swan Song. It is said that Chuck Berry died of a broken heart when His love child (Rock) died in Y2K after a long illness. R.I.P. Rocky Road, or is it Rock & Roll? Or is it Rock Island Line, the 60’s were such a blur to me… Martin’s OCTET: Tony Gilbert, 🎻 violinist, Sidney Sax, Violinist , John Sharpe, Violinist & Juergen Hess, Violinist Stephen Shingles, Viola, John Underwood, Viola Derek Simpson, Celloist, Stephen Landberry, Celloist. Eleanor Rigby, Http://www.Wikipedia.com, Accessed 04JAN2020

Originally, recorded by the Beatles, although credited to John Lennon and Paul McCartney, it was written and sung by Paul. It has been covered, at least, 100 times by artists such as Aretha Franklin, The Fray, Ray Charles, Wes Montgomery, the Four Tops, Rare Earth, Vanilla Fudge, Richie Havens, Jackie Wilson, Joan Baez, Ides of March, Gene Chandler, Alice Cooper, and many others.
